The increasing concerns over greenhouse gas emissions have driven significant research into sustainable carbon utilization strategies. Among these, the catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol has emerged as a promising approach, offering both carbon capture and value-added chemical production. In this study, a Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 (CZA) catalyst was synthesized via an enhanced co-precipitation method with adding polyethylene glycol (PEG) surfactant to improve porosity and surface functionality. Additionally, Ga and Ti were introduced as promoters to enhance catalytic performance. Catalytic performance tests demonstrated that the Ti-doped CZA catalyst (Ti-CZA-3PG) exhibited the highest CO2 conversion (35.6 %) and space-time yield (STY) of methanol (312.6 mmol/(gcat∙h)) at 280 °C under 50 bar, even outperforming a commercial catalyst. The improved performance is attributed to enhanced Cu-ZnO interaction, increased active sites due to oxygen vacancies, and suppression of the reverse water-gas shift reaction, ensuring higher methanol selectivity. This study highlights the synergistic effects of PEG-assisted synthesis and hetero-metal doping, presenting an effective strategy for optimizing Cu-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Graphical Abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Methanol CuZnO/Al2O3 Polyethylene glycol Metal doping Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The growing use of fossil fuels around the world has caused more greenhouse gases to be released, making climate change worse. As a result, cutting down carbon dioxide (CO₂) emissions has become an important global goal [1]. This urgency has spurred widespread efforts to transition towards sustainable energy systems and carbon-neutral technologies. Among the various strategies, methanol synthesis has emerged as a promising pathway for CO2 utilization, offering the dual advantage of capturing carbon while serving as a valuable source for diverse chemical feedstocks and fuels [2]. Methanol, which is used as a reagent to synthesize fuel additives such as methyl tert-butyl ether, a solvent or platform chemical, is one of the most important chemicals in the petroleum and energy industries [3]. In addition, methanol is also being used for hydrogen (H2) transport that is one of the essential technologies in hydrogen-based society [4]. Syngas and CO2 are the two main sources utilized for methanol synthesis [5,6]. Especially, methanol synthesis by CO2 hydrogenation is considered one of the potential directions for eco-friendly and sustainable fuel production chemistry. The reaction for methanol synthesis from CO2 proceeds as shown in Eq. (1) [7]. CO2, a non-polar and linear-symmetric molecule, is a strong electron acceptor [8] and one of the most stable molecules from the thermodynamic point of view [7]. The carbonyl (CO) double bond possesses a high bond energy of 750 kJ/mol, which is significantly greater than the bond energies of C–C (336 kJ/mol), C–O (327 kJ/mol), or C–H (411 kJ/mol) bonds [9]. This suggests that converting CO₂ requires a significant amount of energy. Higher temperatures help activate CO₂, but they also favor the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction, which produces CO and competes with the methanol synthesis pathway during CO₂ hydrogenation [10]. Notably, the formation of water during the reaction causes sintering of the active sites of the catalyst, leading to catalyst deactivation and a decline in the long-term efficiency of methanol synthesis (Eq. (1)) [11]. Therefore, proper catalyst system is required to activate inert CO2 molecules [12]. (1) CO 2 + 3 H 2 ↔ CH 3 OH + H 2 O Δ H ° = − 49.5 kJ / mol To achieve high methanol yield, it is essential to introduce electrons into the CO₂ molecule from oxidizing agent as an electron carrier. Catalysts incorporating transition metals like copper (Cu), manganese (Mn), cobalt (Co), zirconium (Zr), ruthenium (Ru), rhodium (Rh), zinc (Zn), and nickel (Ni) have been widely investigated for their ability to convert carbon dioxide directly into methanol at relatively low temperatures [13,14]. Notably, many studies have shown that the CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 (CZA) catalyst is the most efficient catalyst to hydrogenate CO2 directly to methanol [13]. Since copper can be highly dispersed on metal oxide supports such as Al2O3, due to strong interaction between the metal and the support, copper-based catalysts have been widely utilized to convert CO2 to methanol through hydrogenation [15]. Zn was disclosed to improve copper dispersion and to facilitate CO2 adsorption, thereby enhancing the catalytic efficiency of methanol synthesis [16]. Additionally, Al2O3 improves the stability and exposure of Cu active centers throughout the reaction [5]. So far, CuZn-based catalysts with high dispersion of the metal species and high surface area are normally synthesized via coprecipitation method, but it is still required to develop better preparation method to enhance the metal dispersion and catalytic performances [17]. Recently, many studies have aimed to introduce controlled defects into catalysts to promote oxygen vacancy formation, which can improve active site dispersion or strengthen interactions between the metal and the support [18–23]. Narkhede et al. showed that introducing Ga into the catalyst markedly increased the number of oxygen vacancies, which serve as potential active sites for CO₂ hydrogenation to methanol [24]. Because CO₂ molecules adsorb onto oxygen vacancy sites, the presence of these vacancies on the catalyst surface enhances catalytic performance by facilitating the adsorption and activation of the reactant gases [25]. Also, Kang et al. reported that incorporating Ga into Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts enhanced the reducibility of the catalyst and Cu dispersion, which contributed to the catalyst’s high activity [26]. Behrens et al. reported that Ga3+ acts as a structural promoter by improving the conductivity of ZnO and increasing the concentration of redox-active defect sites, thereby revealing a link between ZnO conductivity and methanol synthesis activity [27]. Moreover, titanium (Ti) plays a stabilizing role in Cu-based catalysts. Huang et al. synthesized Ti-doped CZA for hydrogen production through methanol steam reforming, and found that Ti incorporation reduced the size of CuO particles, enhanced Cu dispersion, and increased the catalyst’s surface area [28]. However, there have been just a few previous trials to incorporate heteroatoms such as gallium (Ga) and Ti into CZA catalysts to enhance further the catalytic activity. The existing studies underscore the importance of compositional tuning in optimizing catalytic performance, suggesting that further research into Ga or Ti doping could be beneficial. In this work, the enhanced method on the co-precipitation was developed by using polyethylene glycol (PEG) as a surfactant to improve the porosity and increase surface functional groups on CZA catalyst that is used in CO2 conversion to methanol. Additionally, the incorporation of Ga and Ti was tested as promoters to further enhance catalytic performance. 2 Materials and method 2.1 Catalyst preparation CZA catalyst with a molar composition of 6:3:1 was synthesized at ambient temperature using a co-precipitation method. In a typical procedure, aqueous solutions of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, and Al(NO3)3·9H2O were simultaneously added, along with a mixed precipitating agent of NaOH and Na2CO3, dropwise into 200 ml of deionized water with vigorous stirring. The pH of the reaction mixture was strictly maintained at 10.0 throughout the precipitation process by adjusting the amount of the alkaline solution. Afterward, the resulting suspension was stirred at 70 °C for 6 h, followed by filtration and washing with deionized water. To enhance porosity, 3 wt% polyethylene glycol (PEG) was incorporated into the filtered catalyst cake. The resulting material was then dried at 110 °C and calcined at 500 °C for 3 h to obtain the final catalyst. The sample synthesized without PEG was referred to as CZA, while the PEG-modified variant was labeled CZA-3PG. Furthermore, to prepare Ti- and Ga-modified catalysts, titanium isopropoxide and Ga(NO₃)₃ were introduced during the co-precipitation step, maintaining a metal molar ratio of Cu:Zn:Al:M (M = Ti or Ga) at 6:2:1:1. These samples were denoted as Ti-CZA-3PG and Ga-CZA-3PG, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were performed by a Belsorp mini II instrument. The samples were degassed at 300 °C for 5 h under vacuum conditions and isotherms were measured at −196 °C. The total surface area and pore volume were calculated by the BET equation and N2 adsorption method, respectively. The pore diameter of mesopores was estimated by the BJH method. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) of the used catalysts was tested on a Rigaku Ultima IV equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source. The patterns were recorded for 2θ values from 20° to 90° at a scanning rate of 8°/min, and the peaks were indexed according to the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS) database. The dispersion and surface area of metallic copper were measured through N2O chemisorption using an Autochem II 2920. Initially, the catalyst was treated in pure He at 250 °C for 2 h to remove adsorbed species, followed by reduction at the same temperature for another 2 h under a 10 % H2/He atmosphere. Afterward, the system was cooled down to 50 °C with He gas and the N2O-chemisorption process was started using 1 % N2O/He gas mixture. The morphological characteristics and surface structure of the samples were examined at different magnifications (100k and 200k) using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) with a SU8010 instrument. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results of used catalysts were obtained from a AXIS SUPRA (NFEC-2020–09–265067) equipped with an Al-Kα X-ray source (hν = 1486.7 eV) at an accelerating voltage of 15 keV with a filament current of 15 mA. The vacuum level during analysis was maintained in the range of 10−9 – 10−8 torr. The pass energy was set to 160 eV for survey spectra and 20 eV for high-resolution spectra. The binding energies of all elements were corrected internally for substrate charging with the C 1 s (284.8 eV). The reduction behavior of the catalyst was investigated using H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) analysis, performed on an AutoChem II 2920. Prior to the analysis, the samples underwent a pretreatment step to remove any adsorbed moisture and impurities. The pretreatment was conducted under an Ar gas flow at a temperature of 300 °C for 3 h with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Following the pretreatment, the H2-TPR analysis was carried out in a 5 % H2/Ar gas mixture with a total flow rate of 30 ml/min. The temperature was ramped from 50 °C to 500 °C at a constant heating rate of 10 °C/min. The hydrogen consumption was monitored using a thermal conductivity detector. 2.3 CO2 to methanol reaction The catalytic performance tests were conducted in a fixed-bed tubular reactor system, as schematically illustrated in Fig. 1. The catalyst bed, consisting of 0.2 g of catalyst mixed with 1.0 g of SiC (silicon carbide) used as a heat diluent, was placed at the center of the reactor and supported by quartz wool. The reactor temperature was controlled using a furnace equipped with a programmable temperature controller, and a pressure regulator maintained the system pressure at 50 bar. The feed gas mixture consisted of CO2 (24 mol%), H2 (72 mol%), and N2 (4 mol%) as a balance gas to make the H2/CO2 ratio 3, simulating stoichiometric conditions favorable for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The total gas flow rate corresponded to a space velocity (SV) of 6000 ml/(gcat∙h). The experiments were conducted at temperatures ranging from 230 °C to 280 °C, with data recorded at intervals of 10 °C. The pressure was maintained at 50 bar throughout the tests. Prior to each experiment, the catalyst was reduced in situ under H2 condition (100 ml/min) at 300 °C for 2 h. The reactor outlet gases were analyzed using an online gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and flame ionization detector (FID) to quantify the concentrations of CO, CH4, methanol, and other products. The selectivity and conversion rates were calculated based on the CO2 input and product distribution. The turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated using the following Eq. (2). (2) TOF CH 3 OH ( s − 1 ) = n CH 3 OH × N A 3600 × S Cu × N S where n CH 3 OH is the space-time yield of methanol, N A is Avogadro’s number, S Cu is surface area of Cu, and N S is the number of Cu atoms per unit surface (1.46 ×1019), a commonly used value in the literature [29]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Pore textural analysis using N2 sorption isotherm The physical characteristics of the catalysts, including specific surface area (SBET), pore volume, and pore diameter, were analyzed using nitrogen sorption isotherms, and the results are summarized in Table 1. All the samples show Type IV isotherms with H1-type hysteresis loops ( Fig. 2), which is consistent with the properties of mesoporous materials. The addition of PEG treatment to pure CZA increased the specific surface area, due to the additional generation of mesopores: the surface area of CZA-3PG was 84.8 m2/g, which is higher than that of CZA (54.0 m2/g). However, the CZA-3PG shows slightly lower pore volume than the sample synthesized without adding PEG. The decrease is attributed to the decrease of mesopore diameter (29.5 nm to 19.9 nm), not to the decrease of porosity. Without the PEG, CZA sample was generated by the aggregation of large crystals possessing larger mesopores (∼ 29.5 nm), while the addition of PEG allows the aggregation of tiny crystals with possessing smaller mesopores (∼ 19.9 nm). The change in pore characteristics after PEG treatment can be explained by the role of surfactant in preventing particle agglomeration to form intercrystalline large mesopores. Surfactant molecules, such as PEG, adsorb on the surface of catalyst precursors, reducing the tendency of primary particles to aggregate into large clusters [30]. This suppression of agglomeration produces smaller and more uniformly dispersed particles that pack more tightly, creating narrower mesopores. Similar trends have been reported in MgO systems prepared via CTAB-assisted synthesis [31]. In this case, the introduction of a small amount of CTAB increased the surface area by 1.41 times but decreased the pore volume by 0.75 times, indicating that the surfactant-mediated prevention of particle aggregation altered the surface area, pore diameter, and pore volume. Zhang et al. [17] also demonstrated that the incorporation of polyethylene glycol (PEG) during the synthesis of CuZn-based catalysts led to an enhancement in their mesopore structure. The PEG treatment promoted the formation of well-developed mesoporous networks and increased surface area, which are critical for catalytic performance. The incorporation of Ga and Ti into the CZA-3PG structure showed the specific surface area similar to that of pure CZA-3PG. After adding Ga and Ti into the synthetic gel of CZA-3PG sample, the surface area and pore volume of the resultant catalysts were 89.9 m2/g and 0.52 cm3/g, and 83.7 m2/g and 0.51 cm3/g, respectively. Although further investigation on the detail mechanism of the formation of CZA-3PG crystals is required, the Ga and Ti species may affect the interaction between PEG and CZA framework. 3.1.2 X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements The XRD patterns of the catalysts are presented in Fig. 3. The diffraction peaks provide information about the crystalline phases present in the samples, specifically identifying the CuO and ZnO phases, which are the primary active components in these catalysts. Prominent diffraction peaks observed at 2θ values of 35.4°, 38.7°, 61.6°, and 66.3° are corresponding to the CuO phase [32], while the diffraction peaks of ZnO appeared at 2θ values of 31.9° and 48.9° [32]. These peaks confirm the presence of CuO and ZnO in the catalysts and indicate that their crystalline structure remain intact across all samples. The consistent intensity and broadness of these peaks suggest that the CuO phase is well-dispersed and retains its stability after PEG treatment and metal doping. For PEG-treated catalysts (CZA-3PG), the intensity of the CuO and ZnO peaks remained relatively consistent compared to CZA, indicating that the PEG treatment does not significantly alter the crystallinity of these active phases. However, slight differences in peak broadening were observed, suggesting minor variations in crystallite size or dispersion due to PEG treatment. 3.1.3 N2O chemisorption analysis The N2O chemisorption analysis ( Table 2) provided the dispersion of Cu species and the corresponding Cu surface area across various catalysts. With the introduction of 3 wt% PEG treatment, both Cu dispersion and surface area showed a slight decrease (6.51 % and 20.10 m2/g) compared to CZA (7.18 % and 22.16 m2/g, respectively). This indicates that PEG treatment may allow the encapsulation of Cu into internal sites of alumina, or alter the distribution of Cu species. On the other hand, metal doping influenced the dispersion and surface area of Cu species. Ga-CZA-3PG and Ti-CZA-3PG exhibited higher Cu dispersion (7.07 % and 6.72 %) and Cu surface area of (21.81 m2/g and 20.74 m2/g) than those of CZA-3PG. These results highlight the role of metal doping in stabilizing Cu species and enhancing their accessibility. 3.1.4 SEM investigation The SEM images in Fig. 4 reveal the morphological differences among the various catalysts. Fig. 4(a) shows the morphology in which small particles of ∼20 nm form large agglomeration on the surface of the CZA catalyst synthesized without PEG. In the case of CZA-3PG, Ti-CZA-3PG, and Ga-CZA-3PG synthesized with PEG. Their aggregates are significantly smaller than those of CZA, with a more uniform particle size distribution. The decrease of the particle size results the increase of the surface area of the catalyst samples with the well-developed mesoporous structures, showing good agreement with the results of N2 sorption isotherm (see Table 1). 3.1.5 XPS measurement The XPS analysis results of Cu 2p and Zn 2p are shown in Figs. 5(a) and 5(b), respectively. The Cu 2p spectra show peaks corresponding to Cu+/Cu0 (at ∼932.8 eV) and Cu2+ (at ∼934.8 eV) [33]. With the incorporation of PEG, the proportion of Cu⁺/Cu0 increases significantly, while Cu2+ decreases, suggesting a partial reduction of Cu species. This trend is further pronounced in the Ga-CZA-3PG sample, where Cu⁺/Cu0 is enhanced, and Cu2+ is further reduced. As a structural modifier, Ga3+ has been demonstrated to strongly promote the stabilization of Cu's intermediate state, and increase the oxygen vacancies concentration in ZnO, enhancing the synergistic interactions between Cu and Zn [34]. These oxygen vacancies not only enhance the reducibility of Cu species but also serve as active sites for redox reactions, improving catalytic performance by increasing oxygen mobility and lowering the energy barrier for Cu reduction. The similar effect was observed in the Ti-CZA-3PG sample, where Cu+/Cu0 increases substantially, while Cu2+ drops dramatically, indicating that Ti facilitates Cu reduction, likely through electronic interactions that stabilize the lower oxidation states. Ti, with a lower electronegativity than Cu, can induce electron transfer from Ti to Cu when doped into Cu-based catalysts. This results in an increase in the electron cloud density on the Cu surface, promoting the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu⁺ or Cu0 [28]. Additionally, Ti4+ in TiO2, due to its high charge, is likely to introduce oxygen vacancies in the CuO lattice to maintain charge balance. The formation of these oxygen vacancies destabilizes the Cu-O bonds, leading to the reduction of Cu2⁺ to a more stable electronic state, further enhancing the reduction of Cu2⁺ to Cu⁺ or Cu0. Thus, Ti doping not only increases the electron density on Cu but also promotes the reduction of Cu2⁺ by facilitating oxygen vacancy formation. The binding energies of Zn oxide (ZnO) and Zn(OH)2 were observed for CZA at approximately 1021.5 eV and 1022.7 eV in Zn 2p3/2 peak, respectively, as shown in previous references [35,36]. After PEG treatment, the binding energy of ZnO did not decrease significantly (1021.3 eV in CZA-3PG), but the intensity of the Zn(OH)2 peak was notably reduced. This suggests that PEG plays a role in modifying the local chemical environment around Zn species, potentially by controlling the solubility of zinc salts. It is known that ethylene glycol can strongly coordinate with Zn2+ ions, which helps prevent nanoparticles from aggregating and controls particle formation [37]. When Ti and Ga were incorporated, the binding energy of ZnO decreased to 1021.1 eV. This shift can be attributed to the higher electronegativity and valence state of Ga (+3) and Ti (+4) compared to Zn (+2), which leads to an increased pull of electron density from the surrounding atoms. The electron-deficient property of Ga and Ti induces changes in the local electron distribution, reducing the electron density around the Zn atoms. This electron deficiency can contribute to the formation of oxygen vacancies in the ZnO structure. Oxygen vacancies are created when oxygen atoms are removed from the crystal lattice, and this process leads to a local electron deficiency. The decreased electron density in the system makes it easier for Zn2+ ions to absorb more electrons, which further lowers the binding energy of the Zn 2p [38]. The increased electron density in ZnO allows for easier electron transfer to Cu species, further enhancing the Cu-ZnO interaction. This electron donation promotes the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu0, strengthening the Cu-ZnO interaction [24]. Comprehensively, the enhanced Cu-ZnO interaction in metal-doped CZA-3PG may provide better dispersion of Cu and increase the number of active sites available for the reaction. To characterize the oxidation states of Ga and Ti, XPS analyses of Ga 2p and Ti 2p were conducted and the results were presented in Fig. 6. The results revealed that the Ga 2p spectra displayed oxidized Ga (Gaδ⁺ (0 < δ ≤ 3)) at 1117.8 eV (Ga 2p3/2) and 1144.4 eV (Ga 2p1/2), as well as metallic Ga (Ga0) at 1116.6 eV and 1143.4 eV [39,40]. The coexistence of partially oxidized Gaδ⁺ and Ga0 suggests that Ga2O3 underwent partial to complete reduction, likely facilitated by oxygen vacancy formation. These vacancies can tune the surface electron density, modify adsorption characteristics, and ultimately enhance catalytic performance by strengthening Cu–ZnO interactions. Similarly, Ti was detected primarily as Ti4+ at 463.2 eV (Ti 2p1/2) and 457.7 eV (Ti 2p3/2), with a fraction present as Ti3+ at 463.0 eV and 456.5 eV. The detection of Ti3+ signals indicates the presence of reduced titanium centers, typically associated with oxygen vacancies in the TiO2 lattice [41]. The simultaneous presence of Gaδ⁺/Ga0 and Ti4+/Ti3+, along with their respective binding energies, confirms that both dopants promote oxygen vacancy formation, which in turn modulates the electronic environment of active sites, facilitates Cu2+ reduction, and enhances overall catalytic activity. To examine the extent of oxygen vacancies formation in the catalyst, the O1s peaks of the catalysts were also analyzed ( Fig. 7). The spectra were deconvoluted into three peaks; O1 (adsorbed oxygen), O2 (undercoordinated oxygen), and O3 (lattice oxygen) [42,43]. For CZA, a relatively large proportions of O1 and O3 peak were observed, suggesting a high amount of lattice oxygen and a low level of oxygen defects. However, in the modified catalysts, including CZA-3PG, Ti-CZA-3PG, and Ga-CZA-3PG, the O1 and O3 peak intensities decreased while the proportions of O2 increased. Notably, Ti-CZA-3PG exhibits the smallest O3 peak and the lowest overall intensity, indicating the highest level of oxygen defects among the samples. These results were further clarified by the calculated relative ratios of oxygen vacancies ( Table 3), which showed the lowest value for CZA (53.4 %), followed by CZA-3PG (71.1 %) < Ga-CZA-3PG (77.0 %) < Ti-CZA-3PG (79.1 %). The increase in oxygen vacancies may enhance oxygen mobility and catalytic reactivity, promoting further interaction with CO2. Moreover, oxygen vacancies stabilize copper catalysts by anchoring Cu atoms, preventing their surface migration, maintaining them in oxidized or partially reduced states (Cu⁺/Cu²⁺), and enabling dynamic redox interactions with the support. Samson et al. [44] explained that the existence of oxygen vacancies helps to stabilize Cu⁺ species adjacent to these defect sites. This mechanism significantly suppresses sintering and prolongs catalytic lifetime. 3.1.6 H2-TPR analysis The H2-TPR profiles of the CZA catalysts were displayed in Fig. 8. It reveals the reducibility of CuO species, divided into three peaks: α, β, and γ. The α peak, representing highly dispersed CuO species, appears at lower temperatures (155 °C). The β peak, attributed to larger CuO particles, contributes most to hydrogen consumption and is observed at higher temperatures (213 °C). The γ peak, related to bulk CuO, appears at 234 °C [33,45–47]. Compared to CZA, PEG-treated and metal-doped catalysts exhibited decreased temperatures in the β region, which is the main peak of CuO reduction, with values of 197.8 °C (CZA-3PG), 202 °C (Ti-CZA-3PG), and 211 °C (Ga-CZA-3PG). This indicates that PEG treatment and metal doping enhanced the oxygen vacancies in the catalysts, facilitating the reduction of CuO [34,48]. In a typical Cu/ZnO catalyst, ZnO interacts with Cu species, influencing their oxidation state and electronic structure. The presence of oxygen vacancies increases the number of free electrons in ZnO, which facilitates electron transfer to Cu species. This electron donation promotes the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu0, strengthening the Cu-ZnO interaction, and lowers the reduction temperature of CuO while increasing H₂ consumption [34,49]. These results are well consistent with the XPS analysis. 3.2 CO2 to methanol reaction All the synthesized CZA catalysts were tested in the reaction of CO2 conversion to methanol. As shown in Fig. 9, all the present catalysts exhibited higher CO2 conversion rates than the commercial catalyst at the medium reaction temperature range, 240∼ 260 °C, highlighting their superior performance under moderate reaction conditions. The enhancement of the CO2 conversion is attributed to the increase of surface area as synthesized with PEG. The promotion effect of Ga and Ti to CZA catalysts was also confirmed, based on the results of catalytic investigation using Ti-CZA-3PG and Ga-CZA-3PG catalysts. The catalysts synthesized without metal doping, such as CZA, and CZA-3PG, show just little improvement on CO2 conversion as the temperature increased above 260 °C. In contrast, Ga- and Ti-doped catalysts exhibited further increases of CO2 conversion, as increasing temperature from 270 °C to 280 °C. Especially, Ti-CZA-3PG achieved the highest conversion of 35.6 % at 280 °C, while the commercial catalyst shows 34.0 % CO2 conversion. The increased CO2 conversion of Ga- and Ti-doped catalysts at high temperature can be attributed to their ability to stabilize the active Cu species and the Cu-ZnO interface, primarily due to the formation of oxygen vacancies, as shown in XPS and TPR results [34]. This stabilization is strongly associated with electron transfer mechanisms introduced by the doped metals. Ti, as an n-type semiconductor, generates a high concentration of electrons that are transferred to CuO, facilitating the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu0 that is the main active species for CO2 hydrogenation [28,50]. Similarly, Ga contributes to the electronic interaction at the Cu-ZnO interface, improving electron density around Cu and enhancing its ability to activate CO2 and promote hydrogenation reactions. These effects collectively stabilize the catalyst structure under reaction conditions and maintain a high level of activity, even at elevated temperatures, ensuring more effective CO2-to-methanol conversion. In addition, oxygen vacancies themselves play a key role in enhancing CO2 conversion and promoting methanol conversion reactions. These vacancies are highly effective in adsorbing CO2, facilitating its activation on the catalyst surface. Such an enhanced CO2 adsorption leads to an increased rate of CO2 conversion, while simultaneously providing an environment that promotes the methanol conversion process. The space-time yield (STY) of methanol across the various catalysts was displayed in Fig. 10. The results show a trend similar to those observed in the CO2 conversion results, with notable differences in performance between the synthesized catalysts and the commercial catalyst. Under 260 °C, all of the synthesized catalysts surpass the commercial catalyst. CZA-3PG shows the highest STY value at 260 °C, reaching 301.5 mmol/(gcat∙h). This superior performance highlights the effectiveness of PEG treatment in enhancing the surface area and activity of Cu species. However, it is noteworthy that while CZA-3PG exhibits superior STY of methanol at moderate temperatures (up to 260 °C), its performance declines at higher temperatures, unlike Ti- and Ga-doped counterparts. This underperformance can be primarily attributed to the absence of stabilizing promoters that facilitate redox-active interface formation. Specifically, CZA-3PG lacks the electronic modifications induced by Ga3+ or Ti4+ dopants, which can enhance Cu+/Cu0 stabilization through increased oxygen vacancy concentration and strengthened Cu–ZnO interaction. Without these structural reinforcements, CZA-3PG is more susceptible to Cu particle sintering or re-oxidation at elevated temperatures, leading to a decline in the number of active sites and methanol productivity. At 280 °C, Ti-CZA-3PG outperforms all other catalysts, achieving the highest methanol STY of 312.6 mmol/(gcat∙h), which significantly exceeds that of the commercial catalyst (300.4 mmol/(gcat∙h)). Ga-CZA-3PG also demonstrates competitive performance at this temperature with a STY value of 307.2 mmol/(gcat∙h), further emphasizing the benefits of metal doping in maintaining catalytic activity under elevated temperature conditions. Tong et al. [51] explained that Ga3+ can partially substitute Zn2+ in the oxide lattice, forming defective ZnGa2O4 spinel structures that stabilize Cu+ species in interstitial sites. These species enhance metal–support interaction and promote the formation of highly dispersed Cu clusters, thereby maintaining catalytic activity and thermal stability at elevated temperatures [51]. In contrast, CZA and CZA-3PG show a gradual decline in STY of methanol at the temperature higher than 260 °C. The enhancement of methanol synthesis activity in Ga- or Ti-doped Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts at high temperature can be attributed to the intensified Cu-ZnO interaction with the increased oxygen vacancies. The formation of a strong Cu-ZnO interaction can stabilize Cu species against reoxidation and enhance CO2 hydrogenation activity [52–55]. Additionally, the presence of high-energy interface sites promotes efficient CO2 activation and suppresses the RWGS reaction, leading to improved STY and selectivity of methanol [56]. The enriched Cu-ZnO interface provides multiple catalytic functions, including the dispersion of active Cu species and the exposure of more synergetic sites for reaction. Such enhancements contribute to the superior STY of methanol observed at higher temperatures. These results underscore the importance of PEG addition and metal doping in maximizing STY of methanol, and Ti-CZA-3PG was confirmed to be the most efficient catalyst across wide temperature range. As shown in Fig. 11, the selectivity of methanol across various catalysts and temperatures reveal notable trends regarding the impact of PEG addition and metal doping on catalytic performance. At 230 °C, the methanol selectivity for all the synthesized catalysts is high, with CZA-3PG and Ti-CZA-3PG achieving selectivity values of 91.5 % and 91.2 %, respectively, surpassing the commercial catalyst's methanol selectivity, 89.7 %. However, as the temperature increases to 280 °C, the methanol selectivity for all catalysts declines. The commercial catalyst retains relatively high methanol selectivity of 87.8 % at 280 °C, while CZA-3PG and Ti-CZA-3PG drop to 84.1 % and 86.5 %, respectively. This decline highlights the increasing contribution of the RWGS reaction at elevated temperatures during the hydrogenation of CO2, which is consistent with the trends observed in other literature as well [57]. Nevertheless, the metal-doped catalysts, Ti-CZA-3PG and Ga-CZA-3PG, exhibit a slower decline in methanol selectivity compared to their non-doped counterparts. For instance, Ti-CZA-3PG maintains methanol selectivity of 86.5 % at 280 °C, which is higher than the 84.1 % observed for CZA-3PG. This improved resistance to side reactions can be attributed to the electronic effects of metal doping and enhanced oxygen vacancies. The selectivity of byproducts (CO, CH4, dimethyl ether (DME)) was described in Fig. 12 and Table 4. The most significant side reactions responsible for reducing methanol selectivity are the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction (3) and methanation reaction (4): (3) C O 2 + H 2 → CO + H 2 O Δ H 298 K = 41.1 kJ / mol (4) C O 2 + 4 H 2 → C H 4 + 2 H 2 O Δ H 298 K = − 165 kJ / mol These reactions compete with the primary CO2-to-methanol conversion, diverting reactants away from methanol production and increasing CO selectivity at higher temperatures [58]. In terms of CO selectivity (Fig. 12(a)), which reflects RWGS activity, increases with temperature, showing an opposite trend to methanol selectivity. At higher temperatures, CO selectivity increases for all catalysts, with CZA and CZA-3PG showing the highest CO selectivity values of 14.3 % and 14.5 %, respectively, at 280 °C. In contrast, metal-doped catalysts, such as Ti-CZA-3PG and Ga-CZA-3PG, maintain lower CO selectivity, at 13.2 % and 12.8 %, respectively. This trend is consistent with the endothermic nature of the RWGS reaction (ΔH 298 K = 41.1 kJ/mol), which is thermodynamically favored at higher temperatures, leading to greater CO formation. Nevertheless, the smaller increase observed for metal-doped catalysts indicates their ability to suppress RWGS activity by stabilizing the Cu–ZnO interface and favoring hydrogenation over CO formation. On the other hand, methanation activity was more strongly inhibited. The selectivity for CH4 (Fig. 12(b)) was highest in CZA, ranging from 0.3 % to 3.7 %, followed by CZA-3PG with a range of 0.3–0.7 %. In Ti-CZA-3PG and Ga-CZA-3PG, the selectivity of CH4 was much lower, either undetectable or at most 0.2 %, which is similar to the CH4 production observed in the commercial catalyst. This pronounced suppression aligns with the exothermic nature of methanation (ΔH 298 K = −165 kJ/mol), which is thermodynamically less favored at elevated temperatures, making its activity more sensitive to kinetic and electronic modifications introduced by metal doping. Meanwhile, the selectivity for DME (Table 4) was very low across all catalysts with values below the detection limit or reaching a maximum of 0.1 %, indicating a negligible amount of Brønsted-Lowry acidity in the catalysts. To better understand the intrinsic performance of the synthesized catalysts, the turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated by normalizing the methanol production rate to the copper surface area ( Fig. 13). In the low-to-moderate temperature range (230–260 °C), the undoped CZA-3PG catalyst displayed the highest TOF values (0.14–0.17 s−1), despite having lower Cu dispersion than CZA. This can be attributed to its significantly larger BET surface area derived from PEG treatment, which enhances mass transport and reactant accessibility to Cu sites, thereby increasing per-site utilization efficiency. Interestingly, both Ga-CZA-3PG and Ti-CZA-3PG exhibited slightly lower TOF values than CZA-3PG in this range, despite their expected promotional effects. However, at elevated temperatures (280 °C), the TOF values of Ti-CZA-3PG (0.17 s−1) and Ga-CZA-3PG (0.16 s−1) became comparable to or higher than that of CZA-3PG (0.16 s−1), which can be attributed to the enhanced oxygen vacancy formation promoted by Ti and Ga dopants, as evidenced by XPS and H₂-TPR analyses. These oxygen vacancies play a pivotal role in strengthening the Cu–ZnO interaction by modulating the local electronic structure, facilitating electron transfer from ZnO to Cu, and stabilizing the active Cu⁰ species against reoxidation. The reinforced Cu–ZnO interface enhances electron mobility and active site availability under high-temperature conditions, enabling more efficient catalytic turnover. Consequently, despite their lower relative performance at lower temperatures, the metal-doped catalysts exhibit superior TOF values at 280 °C due to the vacancy-driven enhancement of Cu–ZnO synergy. Overall, the TOF results highlight that in early-stage mechanistic studies, PEG modification primarily boosts intrinsic site utilization at moderate temperatures, whereas metal doping becomes decisive for preserving and enhancing active site reactivity under high-temperature conditions. This mechanistic distinction aligns with the CO₂ conversion and STY trends, where Ti-CZA-3PG ultimately delivers the highest overall productivity at high reaction temperatures. To investigate the state of Cu after reaction in the CZA-Ti-3PG catalyst, which exhibited superior activity at elevated temperatures, the Cu dispersion was examined. It was 6.72 % before the reaction and slightly higher at 7.07 % after the reaction, suggesting that the Cu species remained stable without agglomeration. Overall, the TOF and dispersion results demonstrate that PEG modification primarily enhances intrinsic site utilization at moderate temperatures, whereas metal doping plays a decisive role in preserving and boosting Cu site reactivity at elevated temperatures. 4 Conclusion The results of this study highlight the superior performance of the metal-doped Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts synthesized via advanced co-precipitation method with adding PEG as surfactants to improve the mesoporosity in the CO2-to-methanol reaction. PEG treatment significantly increased the specific surface area, promoting better dispersion of Cu and ZnO species and enhancing catalytic activity. Furthermore, metal doping with Ti and Ga not only preserved these improvements but also provided resistance to side reactions, as evidenced by the consistent CO2 conversion along with the high production rate and selectivity of methanol. Ti-CZA-3PG emerged as the most effective catalyst, achieving the highest CO2 conversion of 35.6 % and methanol production rate of 312.6 mmol/(gcat∙h) at 280 °C, outperforming both non-doped and even commercial catalyst. These enhancements are attributed to the synergistic effects of Ti and Ga, which stabilize the Cu-ZnO interface by increasing the oxygen vacancies, facilitating electron transfer and mitigating the reverse water-gas shift reaction. Overall, the combination of PEG treatment and selective metal doping presents a robust strategy for developing efficient and stable catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol under industrially relevant conditions. coredata.dc:description: The increasing concerns over greenhouse gas emissions have driven significant research into sustainable carbon utilization strategies. Among these, the catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol has emerged as a promising approach, offering both carbon capture and value-added chemical production. In this study, a Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 (CZA) catalyst was synthesized via an enhanced co-precipitation method with adding polyethylene glycol (PEG) surfactant to improve porosity and surface functionality. Additionally, Ga and Ti were introduced as promoters to enhance catalytic performance. Catalytic performance tests demonstrated that the Ti-doped CZA catalyst (Ti-CZA-3PG) exhibited the highest CO2 conversion (35.6 %) and space-time yield (STY) of methanol (312.6 mmol/(gcat∙h)) at 280 °C under 50 bar, even outperforming a commercial catalyst. The improved performance is attributed to enhanced Cu-ZnO interaction, increased active sites due to oxygen vacancies, and suppression of the reverse water-gas shift reaction, ensuring higher methanol selectivity. This study highlights the synergistic effects of PEG-assisted synthesis and hetero-metal doping, presenting an effective strategy for optimizing Cu-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol.
